Core Course: Intergovernmental Relations and Local Financial Management
Ray C. Rist WBI Evaluation Unit World Bank Natalie Deveaux Advisor Evaluation Analyst (202) 458-5625 (202) 473-1399
Number 22 October 1998
Ebel, Robert (Notation: The World Bank Institute was formerly called the Economic Development Institute (EDI), as reflected in some text)
The Economic Development Institute (EDI) conducted a core course on intergovernmental relations and local financial management on March 16-27, 1998, in Vienna, Austria. The course was created to facilitate well-functioning intergovernmental systems in the context of transition economy reforms. The objectives of this course were threefold: (i) provide an operational framework to raise the level of fiscal policy debate, (ii) build long term capacity through the training of trainers, and (iii) develop a network for cross-country sharing of experiences with best (and failed) practices. The target audience was comprised of senior and mid-level officials in local governments, central ministries that have intergovernmental responsibilities, analysts with research institutes, key academics and selected key journalists.
This course was evaluated by the EDI Evaluation Unit. The evaluation was in the form of a post-course questionnaire asking for participants' opinions on several aspects of the course. It consisted of 45 questions, of which 42 covered 7 categories, 2 assessed overall satisfaction with the course and 1 question assessed whether input was adequately considered during course preparation. The 7 categories were: course relevance, benefits provided, group make-up, methods, time and sequencing, logistics, and trainers. Twenty-four out of 30 participants (80%) responded to the questionnaire. All questions on the evaluation used a 5-point Likert type scale that ranged from 1=minimum to 5=maximum. Results from the evaluation are summarized below. The evaluation also used a set of "rapid response" questionnaires that asked questions directly aimed at specific presenters and their presentations. The same 5-point scale was used to record these opinions. The following is a summary of the evaluation results.
l The two overall questions received favorable responses. The first question asked if the course was a worthwhile use of time (mean=4.30). The second question asked if participants would recommend the course to their colleagues. Twenty-three of the 24 respondents said "yes."
l Comparing the range of mean scores for each of the 6 categories highlights one area that may be focused on in the planning of future courses. The methods category asked for participants' opinions on the presentation, case studies, examples, and practice exercises that were used throughout the course. The range of mean scores for this category was 3.00 to 4.13. The lowest mean score was given for the practice exercises method of instruction.
l The item that received the highest single mean score (4.73) asked participants if administrative assistance was adequate. The items addressing the relevance of the course to future work or functions (mean=4.50) and the extent to which resource persons knew the issues well (mean=4.46) also scored in the upper range of all the  questions asked.
lA noticeable trend in the evaluation was the heterogeneity of opinions on the course. High standard deviations were seen, with a range of standard deviations from .55 for the question addressing the adequacy of administrative assistance to 1.44 for the question addressing properly arranged accommodations. Moreover, a high number of items (19 of 45) received a minimum score of 1 and a maximum score of 5, indicating that respondents' opinions varied significantly. Items receiving a minimum score of 1 and a maximum score of 5 were not concentrated in any specific category of the evaluation. Written comments confirmed the variation in opinions, especially in reference to course content. It is suggested that demographic information (i.e. occupation, gender, education) be collected in future evaluations so that the significance of this heterogeneity of opinions can be investigated further.
lOne evaluation question asked whether participant input was adequately considered during the preparation of the course. This item received a mean score of 2.58, which was the lowest item score.
lSeveral items in the questionnaire clearly addressed the first objective. Questions asked how effectively the course taught policy requirements (mean score=4.00), policy alternatives (mean score=3.71), and policy consequences (mean score=3.83). However, the evaluation questions did not accurately assess the second and third objectives. Future evaluations may include questions that determine whether, after having taken this course, respondents feel better suited to be trainers in their respective countries (objective 2). Also, questions may gauge how much this course provided a forum for sharing of experiences between respondents (objective 3).
lResults from the rapid response questionnaires showed an overall high level of satisfaction with the presenters' methods and the content of their material. Two presenters, however, stood out as having some difficulty with their presentation style. Participants rated them in the mid to lower range of the 5-point scale in their use of valid case examples and in participants' opportunity to ask questions. The ability to pin-point specific performances will give planners the opportunity to work to improve performance in future course offerings.
lOne limitation of this questionnaire was that it was based only on participants' opinions. A pre/post course self-assessment test or cognitive test would be a useful tool to increase the scope of this evaluation. A self-assessment test is useful to learn how much a participant's confidence level on a particular topic has increased. A cognitive test is necessary to determine how much knowledge a participant has actually gained. Either tool would complement the questionnaire in its current form. A second limitation of this evaluation is the chance of 'non-respondent' error. As mentioned, 24 out of 30 participants (80%) responded to the questionnaire. If those that did not respond were, as a group, more (or less) satisfied with the course than the participants that did respond, the results of this evaluation will be skewed. It is therefore important to encourage all participants to respond.
